data.title: "{git}{hg}" in termal window output

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open vscode
2. Click the menu view -> toggle integrated terminal

Produces this  in the output:

```
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.10586]
(c) 2015 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

c:\dev\SchneiderSummerEvent\frontend-site {git}{hg}
```

An the cursor is a few tabs in on the line under that.

Doesn't really effect the terminal in any other way. Just for context I have seen this before when using [cmder](http://cmder.net/) when I switched to Windows 10. Had something to do with Clink.

data.title: VSCode/CodeHelper process is blocking folders (Cordova)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 Professional (7601: Service Pack 1)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Edit some file in VSCode.
2. Try to run cordova (compile, etc)

![process](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1462548/15943923/838f6f1a-2e61-11e6-8114-786da361792d.png)

When i try to compile my app I get the **enotempty directory not empty** because of blocking of vscode/codehelper.

data.title: Added .dsql and .psql filetypes
data.body:
.psql - It appears this is used by PostgreSQL
.dsql - this is used by Microsoft's very own SQL Studio Tools when working with APS/PDW

data.title: Common breakpoint operations should be available in the command palette
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open up the command palette
2. In the command portion type "breakpoint"
3. Notice that common breakpoint operations are not available
### Justification

VS Code does a great job of allowing the user to stay away from the mouse and have a keyboard-only experience.  There are common breakpoint operations (delete all breakpoints, disable all breakpoints, etc.) that developers use frequently to debug.  I believe that these common operations should be available in the command palette and also have configurable key bindings.

data.title: Timeout due to certificate error during "ext install"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

I realize that this has been brought up tangentially in a few other issues (#69 and #155).  However, the issues resolved in both of those are not my current issue.

At my company, market.visualstudio.com is issued a certificate after the https traffic is intercepted.  It seems that VS Code uses the IP 191.238.172.191 when trying to browse/install extensions, which causes a cert problem because the cert was issued to market.visualstudio.com, causing a mismatch.  If I browse to 191.238.172.191, IE and firefox complain, but market.visualstudio.com works just fine.  The computer does not use any proxy settings so the "http.proxyStrictSSL": false setting does not help.  Why is the IP address being used in the first place instead of the hostname?

Any suggestions?

data.title: SyntaxError: Unexpected identifier error in integrated terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: 1511 (10586.420 Enterprise)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set VS Code as the system's default app for opening .txt files
2. Launch the integrated terminal
3. CD to a directory with a .txt file  
4. Type the txt file name and hit Enter

Output in terminal:
C:\Temp>C:\Temp\test.txt:2

data.title: Editor font-family 'Droid Sans Mono' is not working without installing the font on OS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 (Linux 4.4.0)

I have been using Visual Studio Code v1.1 about a month and after I updated it to v1.2 the font 'Droid Sans Mono' is not working on editor, having fallback to monospace:

![vs-code-editor-font](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2215806/15936524/bc8dc750-2e41-11e6-8346-988b2fd8491d.png)

I installed then the 'Droid Sans Mono' font on my OS and is working now, but I think this could be a problem to other people

data.title: Integrated Terminal consumes a lot of memory
data.body:
- VSCode Version: VS Code 1.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open integrated terminal
2. run `ls -lR /Applications` 
3. watch Electron Helpers growing quickly in Activity Monitor:

![2016-06-09_17-19-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/15935062/4b8280a8-2e66-11e6-84e3-fb06abb7f779.png)

Before opening the terminal the renderer was at 169 MB, the 2.24 GB are after about 5 minutes. 

The first process is the Renderer and the second the terminalProcess:

36471 ??         8:11.00 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Electron Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Electron Helper --type=renderer --no-sandbox --lang=en-US --node-integration=true --background-color=#FFFFFF --num-raster-threads=4 --enable-zero-copy --enable-gpu-memory-buffer-compositor-resources --content-image-texture-target=3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,34037,3553,3553,3553,3553,34037,3553,34037,34037 --video-image-texture-target=34037 --channel=36422.3.135030966

38929 ??         0:11.76 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Electron Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Electron Helper ./terminalProcess

/cc @alexandrudima

data.title: Php syntax highlighting in dark (defaul dark) theme

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new file e.g. test.php
2. Copy this:

``` html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8">

    <title>Test</title>
</head>
<body>

<?php $someVar = 'hello'; ?>

<?php $someVar = 'hello'; 

?>

</body>
</html>
```
1. Set the language mode to PHP
2. Select Theme: Dark+ (default dark)
3. You will notice now, that there is some miss matching between a one line of code or when you expand it.

I'm not sure if this just a problem with the theme, how ever the problem appeared when I installed to update to version 1.2 today.

data.title: JavaScript syntax highlighting - ternary operator and string literal
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.2.0 - OS Version: OSX 10.11.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enter the following syntax into vscode: ``` javascript exports.listNames = (request, reply) => { const family = request.params.family const status = request.params.status || 'done' const branch = (status === 'done') ? `master` : `fixes/${family}` const listNames = github.listNames.bind(github, branch) listNames(family) .then((locales) => { reply(locales) }) .catch((err) => { request.log(['error', 'github'], err) reply(err) }) } ``` 1. Anything following the `const branch = (status === 'done') ? `master` : `fixes/${family}` is not highlighted properly

data.title: Rename Symbol goes to undesired places
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Win10x64

`Rename Symbol` can wander off into files, that are undesired to change. Just now I had several lines using `__dirname` global variable, I decided to use an another user defined variable `settings.paths.root` and used `Rename Symbol` it worked fine, except it also went into `.\typings\node\node.d.ts` and changed it there as well... This happens even if I exclude the `typings` dir in `.vscode\settings.json`

data.title: Unwanted Formatting of JS1.7/ES2015 Destructuring Assignment Pattern
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

The built-in formatter does not recognize the new destructuring assignment syntax with curly braces and formats it like normal code blocks, which is potentially unwanted in most of the cases.
It would be perfect to be able to switch it on or of, or even to set a limit, so that it is only formatted as blocks, if there are more than the specified number of items in the list. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an example .js file with desired formatting like this: 
   
   ```
   const electron = require('electron');
   const {app} = electron;
   ```
2. Format the file via _Alt+Shift+F_ resulting in:
   
   ```
   const electron = require('electron');
   const {
       app
   } = electron;
   ```

PS: I just found out that the code highlighting is also different when block-formatted:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1841856/15931729/3aad32c6-2e59-11e6-8073-e9e42785672a.png)
vs.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1841856/15931768/604a6c7e-2e59-11e6-9160-3fbdef5a4c14.png)

data.title: Code completion suggestion disappears after you start manually typing it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Linux version 3.19.0-32-generic 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a new html file
2. Write a  '< div >' tag
3. Start writing the closing tag of the div ( '</' )
4. Right now, VS Code should show 'div' as a possible suggestion
5. However, once you start typing 'd' ( as in 'div' ), the suggestion disappears

I propose showing the suggestion until the user input stops matching the first part of the suggestion. 

I, for one, would find this helpful, because it feels more natural to keep typing instead of moving my fingers towards enter, while still seeing what the closing tag should look like

data.title: Error: NativeScript CLI not found
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 x64
- npm version: 3.9.5
- NodeJS version: 5.11.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install official .deb package from 
2. install [NativeScript](https://github.com/NativeScript/nativescript-cli#install-the-nativescript-cli) extension with npm -g i nativescript 

I had the same issue with previous version 1.1 which was installed with Ubuntu's umake tool. I solved the issue with removing VSCode and install it again from Microsoft's .deb package.
version 1.2. bring this problem again. It can't find globally installed nodes modules. I have same issue/error with other extensions.

I don't have this problem with NativeScript extensions on Windows 10.

Please see attached image. This is voluntarily a picture to show the context of my low brightness screen.
You can see that the background of the selected line (here "default settings") is not contrasted enough.

data.title: Drag and drop TypeScript file does not move associated .js and .map file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: MacOSX current

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Drag drop typescript file from one folder to another
2. The old location still holds the corresponding .js and .map files. they don't get moved (or deleted) and start to appear in the tree view even if .js file display is disabled.

I think they should either be moved or deleted from the old location. Now it requires laborious process of deleting 2 files for each drag drop.

data.title: Save file even without file changes - so that Nodemon, Gulp, Chokidar and other file watchers restart
data.body:
It would be very useful to have VSCode save a file even when no file changes have taken place, because when an error occurs, Nodemon crashes and doesn't restart the app until a save has taken place. 

So even if you want to restart the server without making any file changes - sometimes bugs happen due to a runtime event, it's not always an obvious bug in your code, you have to make some kind of unnecessary change, like typing a space before being able to save, which is annoying.

data.title: Prevent editor pane from scrolling so far
data.body: I often use my trackpad to scroll down to the end of document - and I am used to editors that scroll until the last line is at the bottom of the editor, which I think makes sense and is more useful than scrolling until the last line of the document is at the top of the editor. What do others think of this? - VSCode Version: 1.2 - OS Version: OSX 10.11 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a document 2. Scroll to the end

data.title: Click twice to get cursor from terminal to editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

We need to click twice to get our cursor from integrated terminal to the file we are editing

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file to edit
2. Open embedded terminal
3. Click on terminal and type something.
4. Click on editor(Just above terminal)

If you are editing any *.c file, and you click on opening round bracket, then it will highlight the closing bracket, however the cursor will neither be on terminal nor on editor pane. 
1. Click on editor pane again.

Now the cursor will be on editor pane.
![workspace 1_002](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8456197/15923763/609fb114-2e4c-11e6-8be6-2b8531b82927.png)

data.title: editor.lineHeight or editor.fontSize affects tooltip in editor (screenshot added)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.0
  Commit 809e7b30e928e0c430141b3e6abf1f63aaf55589
  Date 2016-06-06T13:26:59.802Z
  Shell 0.37.6
  Renderer 49.0.2623.75
  Node 5.10.0
- OS Version: Win7 SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set the editor.lineHeight to 12 in settings.json
2. Set the editor.fontSize to 12 in settings.json
3. Set the editor.fontFamiliy to [ProFontWindows](http://www.tobias-jung.de/seekingprofont/) (may not be necessary)
4. Hover over items in the editor (tested with Javascript)

You may need to fiddle with the lineHeight and fontSize settings if you are using a different font.

[Example 1](http://i.imgur.com/PBBokpf.png)
[Example 2](http://i.imgur.com/gyC7GIe.png)

data.title: Tasks documentation for ProblemPattern should explicit mandatory "attributes"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0

When creating a task with a ProblemMatcher and a ProblemPattern, the documentation should explicit the fact that the attributes "file", "line" and "message" are mandatory and must be extracted from the "regexp", otherwise the GUI won't mark the errors or warnings matched by ProblemPattern.

Documentation involved:
https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/editor/tasks
https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks_appendix
